There are plenty more fish in the sea.

There are three "too much" and three "too little" that can bring a fool down: too much spending and too little money; too much talking and too little knowledge; and too much boasting and too little earnings.
There is a great art in selling the wind.
There is a remedy for everything except death.
There is little use in watching a bad woman.
There is luck in leisure.
There is luck in odd numbers.
There is measure in all things.
There is mony a true tale tauld in jest.
There is never a great dunghill at a sportsman's door.
What can't be cured must be endured.
What children hear their parents say by the fireside, they repeat in the highway.
What Christ does not take the exchequer takes.
What cures Sancho makes Martha sick.
What cures the liver harms the spleen.
What does not happen in a year may happen in a moment.
What force cannot do ingenuity may.
What have you to hide from someone who shows you his arse?
What I see with my eyes I can guess with my fingers.
What is another's always pines for its master.
Silence and look out, we shall catch both hen and chicks.
Silent water is dangerous water.
Silly sheep, where one goes, all go.
Since I wronged you, I have never liked you.
Since the house is on fire, let us warm ourselves.
Since we cannot get what we like, let us like what we can get.
Since we have loaves let us not look for cakes.
Since you have scolding me, I have counted a hundred and twenty holes in that nutmeg grater.
Skilled hands eat trouts.
Sleep is the best cure for waking troubles.
With a staircase before you, you look for a rope to go down by.
With bread and wine you can walk your road.
With lightning and with love, the clothes sound, the heart burned.
With money you would not know yourself, without money nobody would know you.
Woe to the house where the hen crows and the rooster is still.
Woe to the mule that sees not her master.
Women and calendars are good only for a year.
Women and melons are at their best when they are really ripe.
Women and wine rid a man of his common sense.
Women, melons, and cheese are bought by the weight.
The sheep that bleats loses a mouthful.
The shirt is nearer than the frock.
The shoemaker's son always goes barefoot.
The smith's dog sleeps at the noise of the hammer, and wakes at the grinding of teeth.
The snail, to be rid of annoyances, bartered its eyes for horns.
The snake that seduced Eve spoke Spanish.
The son of an ass brays twice a day.
The spider's web lets the rat escape and catches the fly.
The spoken word sometimes loses what silence has won.
The spot will come out in the washing.
There is nothing like deprivation to generate thanks for small mercies.
There is some distance between Peter and Peter.
There is truth in wine.
There was already twenty in the family, so my grandmother had a baby.
There wasn't a sound to be heard. You could have heard a pin drop.
There would be no ill word if it were not ill taken.
There's honor among thieves.
There's no accounting for taste.
There's no argument like that of the stick.
There's no making a good cloak of bad cloth.
The oaths of one who loves a woman are not to be believed.
The obscure we see eventually. The completely apparent takes longer.
The official who can't lie may as well be out of the world.
The old for want of ability, and the young for want of knowledge, let things be lost.
The old man at home, and the young abroad, lie after the same fashion.
The old wife, if she does not serve for a pot, serves for a cover.
The one who rings the fire bell is safe.
The one-eyed man is a king in the country of the blind.
The only chaste woman is the one who has not been asked.
The open house makes a good man of the thief.
The threshold says nothing but what it hears of the hinge.
The tide will fetch away what the ebb brings.
The tiger that has once tasted blood is never sated with the taste of it.
The tired ox plants his foot firmly.
The tongue goes to where the tooth aches.
The tongue of a bad friend cuts more than a knife.
The treason pleases, but the traitors are odious.
The Truth will out.
The turd is proud that the river will carry it.
The voice of the people is the voice of God.
Wherries must not put out to sea.
Whether it be so or not, husband, put on your hood.
Whether the pitcher strike the stone, or the stone the pitcher, woe be to the pitcher.
Whether you boil snow or pound it you can have but water of it.
Whether you ignore a pig, or worship that pig from afar, to the pig it's all the same.
Whilst the nurse suckles, we love her; when she is of no further use, she is forgotten.
Whilst the tall maid is stooping, the little one sweeps the house.
Whilst we drink, prank ourselves, with wenches daily, Old age upon's at unawares doth sally.
White hands are no offence.
Whither goest thou, Misfortune? To where there is more.
The wolf and the fox are both in one story.
The wolf changes his teeth but not his disposition.
The wolf commits no mischief at home.
The wolf does that in the course of the week which hinders him from going to mass on Sunday.
The wolf eats of what is counted.
The wolf loses his teeth, but not his inclinations.
The wolf never wants a pretext against the lamb.
The wolf picks up the ass's fleas by moonlight.
The woman in finery, the house in filth, but the doorway swept.
The woman who dresses well attracts the husband from another woman's door.
Money gets money.
Money goes where money is.
Money soothes more than a gentleman's words.
Money turns bad into good.
Money will do more than my lord's letter.
More grows in the garden than the gardener knows he has sown.
More than enough is too much.
More things grow in the garden than the gardener sows.
Moses does not play because he has not the means.
Mother, marry me, marry me, or the gull will fly away with me.
What one does, one becomes.
What the abbot of Bamba cannot eat he gives away for the good of his soul.
What the boss says goes.
What the fool does at last the wise man does at first.
What the she-wolf does pleases the he-wolf.
What three know, everybody knows.
What you dislike for yourself do not like for me.
What you see is what you get.
What's everybody's business is nobody's business.
Whatever way you take there is a league of bad road.
We're all a little crazy in one way or another.
Weight and measure save a man toil.
Welcome, misfortune, if you come alone.
Well begun is half done.
Well-married is when you have no mother-in-law and no sister-in-law.
Were you at the wedding, Molly? No, mother, but the bride was very fine.
Wet kisses are the messengers of the heart.
What a fool does in the end, the wise do in the beginning.
What a woman wills God wills.
What belongs to everybody belongs to nobody.
The righteous man sins before an open chest.
The road of "about," leads only to the house of "never." Near the spring nobody dies of thirst.
the rotten apple spoils its companion.
The scalded cat dreads cold water.
The secret in swimming is to know how to take care of your clothes.
The secret of patience is doing something else in the meantime.
The secret of two no further will go; the secret of three a hundred will know.
The servant wench that has a mother in town swoons seven times a day.
The sharper soon cheats the covetous man.
The sharper the storm, the sooner it's over.
To lather an ass's head is only wasting soap.
To lie and eat fish demand a lot of skill.
To live in fear is a life half-lived.
To love and be wise is impossible.
To mad words deaf ears.
To offer friendship to one who is looking for love, is like giving bread to someone dying of thirst.
To own is to fear.
To swim and swim more, and be drowned on shore.
To take ambition from a soldier, is to rob him of his spurs.
To tell a woman what she cannot do is to tell her what she can.
Take no notice of the stupid things people say.
Take the middle of the way and thou wilt not fall.
Take the will for the deed.
Take what you want, God said to man, and pay for it.
Take what you want, then pay for it.
Taking out and not putting in soon reaches the bottom.
Talk as you go, husband, to the gallows.
Talk little and well, and you will be looked upon as somebody.
Talk much, and err much.
Talk of sporting, and buy game in the market.
The person who plants the lettuce does not always eat the salad.
The pig's tail will never make a good arrow.
The pitcher goes so often to the well, that it leaves its handle or its mouth.
The pitcher that goes often to the well leaves either its handle or its spout there.
The poor man has his crop destroyed by hail every year.
The poor-houses are filled with the honestest people.
The proof of the pudding is in the eating.
The rat that has but one hole is soon caught.
The rat that knows but one hole is soon caught by the cat.
The rich man transgresses the law, and the poor man is punished.
The gardener's feet do no harm to the garden.
The gentle lamb sucks any ewe as well as its mother; the surly lamb sucks neither its own nor another.
The girl as she is taught, the flax as it is wrought.
The glass-dealer's horses fell out, and he looked on to see which kicked hardest.
The goat can't well cover herself with her tail.
The golden ass passes everywhere.
The gossips fall out and tell each other truths.
The grapes are sour, said the fox, when he could not get at them.
The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
The grass looks greener on the other side of the fence.
The ox comes to the yoke at the call of his feeder.
The ox spoke and said "Moo."
The ox that butted me tossed me into a good place.
The ox without a bell is soon lost.
The patient who names a doctor his heir makes a big mistake.
The paunch warm, the foot sleepy.
The pearls of a bride on her wedding day are the tears that will be shed later.
The pen is mightier than the sword.
spanish.description: Trying to convince people with ideas and words is more effective than trying to force people to do what you want.

spanish.text: The person seeking India's riches must have them within himself.
The person that makes one basket can make a hundred.
We are both carriers, and shall meet on the road.
We are not roasting, and already we are basting.
We are not yet roasting, and already we make sops in the pan.
We do not know what is good until we have lost it.
We have been fools once in our lives.
We have no son, and yet are giving him a name.
We have not yet saddled, and are already mounted.
We make more enemies by what we say than friends by what we do.
We must live by the living, not by the dead.
We'll just have to make do.
Leave the jest at its best.
Let bygones be bygones.
Let every man mind his own business.
Let every sheep hang by it own foot.
Let every tub stand on its own bottom.
Let fools and wind pass.
Let him not complain of being cheated who buys cloth by the pattern.
Let him play the instrument who knows how.
Let him that has a mouth not say to another, Blow.
Let him who does not know you buy you.
She is well married who has neither mother-in-law nor sister-in-law.
She stoops to conquer.
She who loves an ugly man thinks him handsome.
Shoemaker stick to your last.
Shoemakers go to mass and pray that sheep may die.
Shoot at a pigeon and kill a crow.
Short hose must have long points.
Shut your door, and you will make your neighbour a good woman.
Shyness is the prison of the heart.
Sickly women live longer.
To err is human, to forgive divine.
To every evil doer his evil day.
To find oneself in tight breeches.
To flee and to run are not all one.
To forget a wrong is the best revenge.
To friend and foe alike I tell them how bad she is, so that I don't have to share her with anyone.
To give is honour, to love is grief.
To give too much when little is asked is a form of refusal.
To him that watches, everything is revealed.
To him who gives you a capon you may spare a leg and a wing.
The wages of sin is death.
The wedding feast is not made with mushrooms only.
The well-bred hound, if he does not hunt to-day will hunt to-morrow.
The well-dressed woman draws her husband away from another woman's door.
The well-fed sheep makes a cloak of its tail.
The wind changes every day; a woman changes every second.
The winter is gone, the spring is come, a fly for those who us good have done.
The wise hand does not all that the tongue says.
The wise knows that he does not know; the ignoramus thinks he knows.
The wise man does not hang his knowledge on a hook.
What is done, is done for this time.
What is in use, wants no excuse.
What is mine is my own; my brother Juan's is his and mine.
What is much desired is not believed when it comes.
What is new cannot be true.
What is not yours always chirps for its master.
What is whispered in your ear tell not to your husband.
What much is worth comes from the earth.
What must be, must be.
What my neighbour eats does my stomach no good.
You used to be a baker, though now you wear gloves.
You want better bread than wheaten.
You will not be loved if you care for none but yourself.
You're casting pearls before swine.
You've made bed, and now you'll have to lie in it.
Your cracked jug seems better to me than my sound one.
No joy without alloy.
No king was ever a traitor, or pope excommunicated.
No man is quick enough to enjoy life to the full.
No need to seek shelter for an old ox.
No offense taken when none is meant.
No one will notice in the dark.
No one would be an innkeeper but for money.
No relation is poor.
No revenge is more honorable than the one not taken.
Opportunity only knocks once.
Order and do it, and you will be rid of anxiety.
Other folks' cares kill the ass.
Out of debt, out of danger.
Out of love for the ox, the wolf licks the yoke.
Out of sight out of mind.
Out of the fullness of the heart the mouth speaks.
Out of the fulness of the heart the mouth speaketh.
Out of thine own mouth will I judge thee.
Paid workmen have no arms.
Through not spending enough we spend too much.
Throw that bone to another dog.
Throwing your cap at a bird is not the way to catch it.
Tie up the hen that eats at your place and lays eggs elsewhere.
Time and I against any two.
Time and tide wait for no man.
To a depraved taste sweet is bitter.
To a hard knot a hard wedge.
To a hasty demand a leisure reply.
To a son-in-law and a hog you need show the way but once.
No revenge is more honourable than the one not taken.
No rogue like the godly rogue.
No woman is ugly when she is dressed.
No wonder if he breaks his head who stumbles twice over one stone.
No work, no money.
Nobody sows a thing that will not sell.
None so deaf as he that will not hear.
Not all things have to be scrutinized, nor all friends tested, not all enemies exposed and denounced.
Not everyone who wears spurs owns a horse.
Not he gives who likes, but who has.
So yourself be good, a fig for your grandfather.
Soft and fair goes far.
Some day Peter will command as much as his master.
Some go to law, for the wagging of a straw.
Some have the fame, and other card the wool.
Sometimes the remedy is worse than the disease.
Sorrows are valuable treasures that you only show to your friends.
Soup must be hot -- insults cold.
Sour wine, old bacon, and rye bread keep a house rich.
Sow corn in clay, and plant vines in sand.
Where there's smoke, there's fire.
Where there's whispering, there's lying.
Where they eat your meat let them pick the bones.
Where you father has been with ink, go not you with a bag.
Where you lose nothing, you always win something.
Where you lost your cloak, seek it.
Where you smart there I will hit you.
Where you think there is bacon, there are not even hooks for it.
Wherever you are, do as you see done.
Wherever you may be, do as you see done.
When one wolf eats another, thee is nothing to eat in the wood.
When our daughter is married sons-in-law are plenty.
When our enemy flies, build him a golden bridge.
When passion entereth at the fore-gate wisdom goes out at the postern.
When poor, liberal; when rich, stingy.
When the bee sucks, it makes honey, when the spider, poison.
When the cat's away the rats will play.
When the cat's away, the mice will play.
When the child cuts its teeth, death is on the watch.
When the corsair promises masses and candles, it goes ill with the galley.
Mother, what is marrying? Spinning, bearing children, and crying, daughter.
Much never cost little.
Much pleasure and little grief is every man's desire.
Much talking, much erring.
My daughter-in-law tucked up her sleeves, and upset the kettle into the fire.
My gossips don't like me because I tell them truths.
My life and soul, but not my pack-saddle.
My neighbour's goat gives more milk than mine.
My neighbour's hen lays more eggs than mine.
My sister's son is a kinsman beyond dispute.
When the river makes no noise, it is either dried up or much swollen.
When the Spaniard sings he is either stupid or without money.
When the spleen increases, the body diminishes.
When the steed is stolen, you shut the stable door.
When the summer is winter, and the winter is summer, it is a sorry year.
When there are two friends to one purse, one sings, the other weeps.
When there is a famine, no bread is stale.
When there is a war between fire and water, fire loses.
When there is real danger, the dogs don't bark.
When they give you the calf, be ready with the halter.
Where the heart is past hope, the face is past shame.
Where the river is deepest it makes the least noise.
Where the sea goes let the sands go.
Where the wolf gets one lamb he looks for another.
Where there is love, there is pain.
Where there is no want of will, there will be no want of opportunity.
Where there's a will there's a way.
Where there's fire there's smoke.
Where there's gossiping, there's lying.
Where there's muck, there's money.
When you are an anvil, bear; when you are a hammer, strike.
When you are at Rome do as Rome does.
When you are on the road speak not ill of your enemy.
When you are talking about marriage, think about your mother.
When you can't get bread, oat-cakes are not amiss.
When you can't get meat, chickens and bacon are good.
When you die, your trumpeter will be buried.
When you eat new bread, don't drink water.
When you go to a strange house knock at the door.
Where force prevails, right perishes.
When the devil finds the door shut he goes away.
When the devil says his prayers he wants to cheat you.
When the Devil was sick the Devil a monk would be, When the Devil got well, the devil a monk was he.
When the fields yield not, the saints have not.
When the flatterer pipes, the devil dances.
When the iron is hot, then is the time to strike.
When the old dog barks, he gives counsel.
When the ox falls, there are many that will help to kill him.
When the prior plays cards, what will the monks do?
When the rabbit has escaped, comes advice.
When a fool has made up his mind the market has gone by.
When a fox is in his hole, the smoke fetches him out.
When a friend asks, there is no tomorrow.
When a good offer comes for your daughter, don't wait till her father returns from market.
When a goose dances, and a fool versifies, there is sport.
When a man is not used to breeches the seams gall him.
When a peasant gets rich, he knows neither relations nor friends.
When an old man cannot drink, prepare his grave.
When drink enters, wisdom departs.
When drums beat, laws are silent.
When I was born I wept, and every day brings a reason why.
When ill-luck sleeps, let no one wake her.
When it rains in August, it rains honey and wine.
When it rains in February, it will be temperate all the year.
When it rains, it pours.
When love is not madness, it is not love.
When misfortune sleeps, let no one wake her.
When one door shuts, a hundred open.
When one door shuts, another opens.
When one is hungry everything tastes good.
Two cannot fall out if one does not choose.
Two false men to one traitor.
Two great talkers never go far together.
Two great talkers will not travel far together.
Two in distress makes sorrow less.
Two of a trade can never agree.
Two of a trade never agree.
Two sparrows on one ear of corn never agree.
Under a bad cloak there is a good tippler.
Under a gold sheath a leaden knife.
To a woman and a magpie tell your secrets in the marketplace.
To be a merchant, the art consists more in getting paid than in making sales.
To be like the esquire of Guadalaxara, who knew nothing in the morning of what he said at night.
To be like the tailor of Campillo, who worked for nothing, and found thread.
To beards with money cavaliers pay respect.
To change one's mind is rather a sign of prudence than ignorance.
To deny all, is to confess all.
To deny everything is to confess everything.
To drunken mothers-in-law give full jugs.
To eat and to scratch one has but to begin.
Luck comes to those who look after it.
Lying and gossiping go hand in hand.
Mad love--I for you, and you for another.
Make a bridge of silver for the flying enemy.
Make good flour, and do not blow the trumpet.
Make sure you have many books and many friends -- as long as they are good ones.
Make way for a madman and a bull.
Make your bargain before beginning to plow.
Man cannot live by bread alone.
Man is fire, woman is tow; the devil comes with a bellows.
You are what you own.
You can judge a man by the company he keeps.
You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make it drink.
You can't catch trout with dry breeches.
You can't have more bed-bugs than a blanket-full.
You can't have more bugs than a blanketful.
You can't have your cake and eat it too.
You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs.
You can't make bricks without straw.
You can't make pancakes without breaking eggs.
Whither goest thou, sorrow? Whither I am used to go.
Whither shall the ox go, where he will not have to plough?
Who arrays himself in other men's garments is stripped on the highway.
Who gives the bread lays down the authority.
Who gives what he has before he is dead, take a mallet and knock that fool on the head.
Who gossips with you will gossip about you.
Who has no bread to spare should not keep a dog.
Who has nothing fears nothing.
Who has time yet waits for time, comes to a time of repentance.
When they offer you a ring, hold out your finger.
When thieves fall out the thefts come to light.
When thieves fall out, honest men come by their own.
When thou seest thy house in flames, go warm thyself by it.
When three people call you an ass, put on a bridle.
When two are in love, only one needs to eat.
When two friends dip into their purse, one laughs, the other cries.
When war begins the devil makes hell bigger.
When we ask a favour, we say, Madam; when we obtain it, what we please.
When we think to catch we are sometimes caught.
Where friars abound keep your eyes open.
Where God has his church the Devil will have his chapel.
Where God sends babbies he sends penny loaves.
Where luck is wanting, diligence is useless.
Where MacGregor sits at the head of the table.
Where man is not, nature is barren.
Where one door is shut another opens.
Where one door shuts another opens.
Where shall the ox go and not plough?
Where the goat leaps, leaps that which sucks her.
Trust not your gossip to a priest who has been a friar.
Trust not your money to one whose eyes are bent on the ground.
Truth and oil, always come to the surface.
Truth, like oil, always comes to the surface.
Truths and roses have thorns about them.
Try to strike a happy medium.
Two birds of prey do not keep each other company.
Two blacks don't make a white.
Two boys are half a boy, and three boys are no boy at all.
Two can play at that game.
There's no smoke without fire.
There's no substitute for experience.
There's nothing so queer as folk.
They are rich who have friends.
They may whip me in the market-place, so it be not known at home.
They took away the mirror from me because I was ugly, and gave it to the blind woman.
They turn night into day.
They two agreed like two cats in a gutter.
They whip the cat, if our mistress does not spin.
They who don't keep goats and yet sell kids, where do they get them?
Women, wind, and fortune, soon change.
Words must be weighed not counted.
Words will not do for my aunt, for she does not put faith even in deeds.
Work improves the harvest better than the field itself.
Working and painting are better from a distance.
Wounds from the knife are healed, but not those from the tongue.
Wounds heal, but not ill words.
Wounds pain most when grown cool.
Wrinkles are the gravestones of love.
Yesterday a cowherd, to-day a cavalier.
When every one says you are an ass, bray.
When fire and water are at war, it is the fire that loses.
When flatterers meet the devil goes to dinner.
When fortune knocks upon the door open it widely.
When God gives light he gives it for all.
When God pleases, it rains in fair weather.
When God pleases, it rains with every wind.
When God will not, the saints cannot.
When good cheer is lacking, our friends will be packing.
When he was born, Solomon passed by his door, and could not go in.
Who is always prying into other men's affairs, leads a dangerous life.
Who is to bell the cat?
Who is to carry the cat to the water?
Who is well seated, let him not budge.
Who is your enemy? A man of your own trade.
Who knows most says least.
Who knows most speaks least.
Who lends recovers not; or if he recovers, recovers not all; or if not all, not much; of if much, a mortal enemy.
Who preaches in the desert loses his sermon.
Who receives a gift, sells his liberty.
Who stumbles without falling makes a bigger step.
Who talks much, errs much.
Who ventures nothing has no luck.
Who wings, drives away care.
Whoever falls sick of folly, is long in getting cured.
Whom God loves, his bitch litters pigs.
Whom the gods love die young.
Whom the gods would destroy, they first make mad.
Whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth.
Do not spread your corn to dry at an enemy's door.
Do not stand in a place of danger trusting in miracles.
The hen's eyes are where her eggs are.
You a lady, I a lady, who is to put the sow out of doors?
A church stone drops gold.
Friends and mules fail in hard trials.
He that is unkind to his own will not be kind to others.
He that is won with a nut, may be lost with an apple.
He who plays with a sword plays with the devil.
I see by my mother-in-law's eyes when the devil takes hold of her.
The bad neighbour gives a needle without thread.
The cow that does not eat with the oxen, either eats before or after them.
The devil is fond of his own.
The fox goes through the corn and does not eat, but brushes it down with his tail.
El hábito no hace al monje.
spanish.description: The habit doesn't make the monk. (Clothes do not make the man.)

spanish.text: A beber y a tragar, que el mundo se va a acabar.
spanish.description: Here's to drinking and swallowing, for the world is going to end. (Eat, drink and be merry, for tomorrow we die.)

spanish.text: Algo es algo; menos es nada.
spanish.description: Something is something; less is nothing. (It's better than nothing. Half a loaf is better than none.)

spanish.text: No hay que ahogarse en un vaso de agua.
spanish.description: It isn't necessary to drown oneself in a glass of water. (Don't make a mountain out of a molehill.)

spanish.text: Borra con el codo lo que escribe con la mano.
spanish.description: He/she erases with the elbow what his/her hand is writing. (Whatever good actions or decisions he makes, he invalidates by other actions)

spanish.text: Dame pan y dime tonto.
spanish.description: Give me bread and call me a fool. (Think of me what you will. As long as I get what I want, it doesn't matter what you think.)

spanish.text: La cabra siempre tira al monte.
spanish.description: The goat always heads toward the mountain. (The leopard doesn't change its spots. You can't teach an old dog new tricks.)

spanish.text: El amor todo lo puede.
spanish.description: Love can do it all. (Love will find a way.)

spanish.text: A los tontos no les dura el dinero.
spanish.description: Money does not last for fools. (A fool and his money are soon parted.)

spanish.text: De músico, poeta y loco, todos tenemos un poco.
spanish.description: We all have a little bit of musician, poet and crazy person in ourselves. (We're all a little bit crazy.)

spanish.text: Al mejor escribano se le va un borrón.
spanish.description: To the best scribe comes a smudge. (Even the best of us make mistakes. Nobody's perfect.)

spanish.text: Camarón que se duerme se lo lleva la corriente.
spanish.description: The shrimp that falls asleep is carried by the current. (Don't let the world pass you by. Stay alert and be proactive. Don't fall asleep at the wheel.)

spanish.text: A lo hecho, pecho.
spanish.description: To what is done, the chest. (Face up to what is. What is done is done.)

spanish.text: Nunca es tarde para aprender.
spanish.description: It never is late for learning. (It is never too late to learn.)

spanish.text: A otro perro con ese hueso.
spanish.description: To another dog with that bone. (Tell that to someone who will believe you.)

spanish.text: Desgracia compartida, menos sentida.
spanish.description: Shared misfortune, less sorrow. (Misery loves company.)

spanish.text: Donde hay humo, hay fuego.
spanish.description: Where there's smoke, there's fire.

spanish.text: No hay peor sordo que el que no quiere oír.
spanish.description: There is not a worse deaf person than the one who doesn't want to hear. (There is none so blind as he who will not see.)

spanish.text: No vendas la piel del oso antes de cazarlo.
spanish.description: Don't sell the bear's hide before you hunt it. (Don't count your chickens before they hatch.)

spanish.text: Qué bonito es ver la lluvia y no mojarse.
spanish.description: How nice it is to see the rain and not get wet. (Don't criticize others for the way they do something unless you've done it yourself.)

spanish.text: Nadie da palos de balde.
spanish.description: Nobody gives sticks for free. (You can't get something for nothing. There's no such thing as a free lunch.)

spanish.text: Los árboles no están dejando ver el bosque.
spanish.description: The trees aren't allowing one to see the forest. (You can't see the forest for the trees.)

spanish.text: El mundo es un pañuelo.
spanish.description: The world is a handkerchief. (It's a small world.)

spanish.text: A cada cerdo le llega su San Martín.
spanish.description: Every pig gets its San Martín. (What goes around comes around. You deserve what you get. San Martín refers to a traditional celebration in which a pig is sacrificed.)

spanish.text: Consejo no pedido, consejo mal oído.
spanish.description: Advice not asked for, advice poorly heard. (Someone who doesn't ask for advice doesn't want to hear it. Don't give advice unless you're asked.)

spanish.text: Obras son amores y no buenas razones.
spanish.description: Acts are love and good reasons aren't. (Actions speak louder than words.)

spanish.text: Gobernar es prever.
spanish.description: To govern is to foresee. (It is better to prevent problems than to fix them. An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.)

spanish.text: No dejes camino viejo por sendero nuevo.
spanish.description: Don't leave the old road for a new trail. (It's better to stick with what works. A shortcut isn't always quicker.)

spanish.text: La lengua no tiene hueso, pero corta lo más grueso.
spanish.description: The tongue doesn't have a bone, but it cuts the thickest thing. (Words are more powerful than weapons.)

spanish.text: La raíz de todos los males es el amor al dinero.
spanish.description: The root of all evils is love toward money. (Love of money is the root of all evil.)

spanish.text: Más vale pájaro en mano que cien volando.
spanish.description: A bird in the hand is worth more than 100 flying. (A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.)

spanish.text: Ojos que no ven, corazón que no siente.
spanish.description: Eyes that do not see, heart that does not feel.

spanish.text: No por mucho madrugar amanece más temprano.
spanish.description: Not through much awaking early does the dawn come earlier.

spanish.text: El amor es ciego.
spanish.description: Love is blind.

spanish.text: Perro que no camina, no encuentra hueso.
spanish.description: The dog that doesn't walk doesn't find a bone. (You can't succeed if you don't try.)

spanish.text: Dime con quién andas y te diré quién eres.
spanish.description: Tell me with whom you walk and I will tell you who you are. (A man is known by the company he keeps.)

spanish.text: El diablo sabe más por viejo que por diablo.
spanish.description: The devil knows more due to being old than by being the devil.

spanish.text: A la luz de la tea, no hay mujer fea.
spanish.description: By the light of the torch there is no ugly woman.

spanish.text: Haz el bien, y no mires a quién.
spanish.description: Do the good, and don't look at whom. (Do what is right, not what will gain approval.)

spanish.text: El que nació para tamal, del cielo le caen las hojas.
spanish.description: The leaves fall from the sky for him who was born for the tamal (a traditional Mexican food made from corn leaves).

spanish.text: No hay mal que por bien no venga.
spanish.description: There is no bad from which good doesn't come.

spanish.text: Quien no tiene, perder no puede.
spanish.description: He who doesn't have is unable to lose. (You can't lose what you don't have.)

spanish.text: No todo lo que brilla es oro.
spanish.description: Not all that shines is gold. (Not everything that glitters is gold.)

spanish.text: Perro que ladra no muerde.
spanish.description: The dog that barks doesn't bite.

spanish.text: A caballo regalado no se le mira el diente.
spanish.description: Don't look at the tooth of a horse that was given. (Don't look a gift horse in the mouth.)

spanish.text: Eso es harina de otro costal.
spanish.description: That is wheat from a different bag. (It's a bird of a different feather.)

spanish.text: De tal palo, tal astilla.
spanish.description: From such a stick, such a splinter. (A chip off the old block.)

spanish.text: Para el hombre no hay mal pan. (O, para el hambre no hay mal pan.)
spanish.description: ) There is no bad bread for man. (Or, there is no bad bread for hunger.)

spanish.text: Las desgracias nunca vienen solas.
spanish.description: Misfortunes never come alone. (Bad things happen in threes.)

spanish.text: De buen vino, buen vinagre.
spanish.description: From good wine, good vinegar.

spanish.text: El que la sigue, la consigue.
spanish.description: He who follows it attains it. (You get what you work for.)

spanish.text: Saliste de Guatemala y te metiste en Guatepeor.
spanish.description: You left Guate-bad and went to Guate-worse.

spanish.text: A quien madruga, Dios le ayuda.
spanish.description: God helps the one who arises early. (God helps those who help themselves. The early bird catches the worm. Early to bed, early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise.)

spanish.text: Camarón que se duerme, se lo lleva la corriente.
spanish.description: The shrimp that falls asleep gets carried away by the current.

spanish.text: Del dicho al hecho, hay mucho trecho.
spanish.description: From the saying to the act, there is much distance. (Saying something and doing it are two different things.)

spanish.text: Si quieres el perro, acepta las pulgas.
spanish.description: If you want the dog, accept the fleas. (If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. Love me, love my faults.)

spanish.text: De noche todos los gatos son negros.
spanish.description: At night all cats are black.

spanish.text: Lo que en los libros no está, la vida te enseñará.
spanish.description: That which isn't in books, life will teach you. (Life is the best teacher.)

spanish.text: La ignorancia es atrevida.
spanish.description: Ignorance is courageous.

spanish.text: Cada uno lleva su cruz.
spanish.description: Everyone carries his cross. (We each have our own cross to bear.)

spanish.text: A falta de pan, tortillas.
spanish.description: Lack of bread, tortillas. (Make do with what you have. Half a loaf is better than none.)

spanish.text: El amor es como el agua que no se seca.
spanish.description: Love is like water that never evaporates. (True love lasts forever.)

spanish.text: No dejes para mañana lo que puedas hacer hoy.
spanish.description: Don't leave for tomorrow that which you can do today.

spanish.text: Donde no hay harina, todo es mohina.
spanish.description: Where there's no flour, everything is an annoyance. (Poverty breeds discontent. If your needs aren't met, you won't be happy.)

spanish.text: Todos los caminos llevan a Roma.
spanish.description: All roads lead to Rome. (There's more than one way to reach a goal. All actions have the same result.)

spanish.text: Tomorrow is often the busiest day of the week
An ounce of blood is worth more than a pound of friendship
Two great talkers will not travel far together
He who has no shame has no conscience.
Tomorrow’s remedy will not ward off the evil of today.
Don’t believe what you see, but only what I tell you.
A bad man’s gift is like his master.
A blind man’s stroke, which raises a dust from beneath water.
A blind man’s wife needs no paint.
A boy’s love is water in a sieve.
A capon eight months old is fit for a king’s table.
A devotee’s face, and a cat’s claws.
A dog won’t bite you if you are carrying a stick.
A father’s love, for all other is air.
A good man’s pedigree is little hunted up.
A good paymaster is keeper of other men’s purses.
A great man’s entreaty is a command.
A lawsuit for a maravedi consumes a real’s worth of paper.
A malicious man is like a coal sack — black on the outside and even blacker inside.
A peck of March dust is worth a king’s ransom.
A pig’s tail will never make a good arrow.
A Portuguese apprentice who can’t sew, yet would be cutting out.
A rich man’s foolish sayings pass for wise ones.
A rule isn’t unfair if it applies to everyone.
A secret between two is God’s secret, a secret between three is everybody’s.
A shoemaker’s wife and a smith’s mare are always the worst shod.
A son-in-law’s friendship is a winter’s sun.
A wolf’s mourning is the fox’s feast.
A woman’s advice is of little value, but he who does not take it is a fool.
A woman’s belly is a garden with many fruits.
A woman’s place is in the home.
A woman’s tears and a log’s limping are not real.
A woman’s tears are worth a lot, but cost little.
All’s fish that comes to the net.
All’s for the best in the best of all possible worlds.
All’s lost that’s put in a riven dish.
All’s not lost that’s in danger.
An ounce of wit that’s bought Is worth a pound that’s taught.
Another’s bread costs dear.
Another’s care hangs by a hair.
Ask not after a good man’s pedigree.
At the game’s end we shall see who gains.
Beggars can’t be choosers. For a good appetite there is no hard bread.
spanish.description: If someone gives you free things or offers to help you do something, you can’t ask for a different color or choose the perfect time in your schedule. When you receive free help or goods, you should accept what you’re offered—you can’t be picky (a “chooser”) because you’re not paying!

spanish.text: Begin in other people’s way so as to end by having your own way.
Better is the smoke of my own house than the fire of another’s.
Better visit hell in your lifetime than after you’re dead.
Between the "yes" and "no" of a woman you can’t place a pin.
Blow, smith, and you’ll get money.
Carry bread in your hood to Don Garcia’s wedding.
Changing one’s mind is more often a sign of prudence than of ignorance.
Clergymen’s sons always turn out badly.
Come live with me and you’ll know me.
Compare your grieves with other men’s and they will seem less.
Copper begets copper, and not the labour of men’s bones.
Cow of many — well milked and badly fed.
Death is the reaper who doesn’t take a midday nap.
Dios tarda pero no olvida — God delays but doesn’t forget.
Do not buy a carrier’s ass, or marry an innkeeper’s daughter.
Do not stuff your servant with bread, and he won’t ask for cheese.
Don’t bite off more than you can chew.
spanish.description: If you take a bite of food that’s too big, you won’t be able to chew! Plus you could choke on all of that extra food. It’s the same if you take on more work or responsibility than you can handle—you will have a difficult time. So it’s best not to get involved in too many projects, because you won’t be able to focus and get them all done well.

spanish.text: Don’t leave for tomorrow that which you can do today.
Don’t let anyone know about your silent [secret] money.
Don’t sign a paper without reading it, or drink water without seeing it.
Don’t speak unless you can improve on the silence.
Don’t talk too much—your ignorance exceeds your knowledge.
Don’t be afraid of a spot that can be removed with water.
Don’t believe what you see, husband, but only what I tell you.
Don’t bet more than you can afford to lose.
Don’t call me a little olive until you’ve picked me.
Don’t kill the man at the count’s desire.
Don’t let anyone know about your secret money.
Don’t offer me advice; give me money.
Don’t refuse a wing to the one who gave you the chicken.
Don’t scuffle with the potter, for he makes money by the damage.
Don’t send away your cat for being a thief.
Don’t spoil the ship for a halfpenny-worth of tar.
Don’t stop the way of a bull or of a current of air.
Don’t take any wooden nickles.
Don’t talk too much — your ignorance exceeds your knowledge.
Don’t talk too much, because your ignorance is greater than your knowledge.
Don’t worry if people call you ordinary — only if you are ordinary.
Every man is a fool in some man’s opinion.
Every one in his own house, and God in all men’s.
Every one wishes to bring water to his own mill, and leave his neighbour’s dry.
Every person is a fool in some person’s opinion.
Everybody’s friends and nobody’s friend is all one.
Expect not at another’s hand what you can do by your own.
Fear the man of one book.
Feed the raven and he’ll peck out your eyes.
Fools and the perverse fill the lawyers’ purse.
For all one’s early rising, it dawns none the sooner.
For whom does the blind man’s wife adorn herself?
Four things put a man beside himself–women, tobacco, cards, and wine.
Fox’s broth, cold and scalding.
From my gossip’s bread a large piece for my godson.
Give a clown your foot, and he’ll take your hand.
Give a thing and take a thing, to wear the devil’s gold ring.
Go in God’s name, for he takes a loaf of mine.
Go not every evening to your brother’s house.
Go to your aunt’s house, but not every day.
God delays but doesn’t forget.
Grass doesn’t grow on a busy street.
Happiness itself does not stay — only moments of happiness do.
He knows it as well as his Lord’s Prayer.
He that does not show himself is overlooked.
He that eats the king’s geese shall be choked with the feathers.
He that has an hour’s start will not be hanged.
He that is born to be hanged shall never be drowned. You can’t escape your destiny.
He that marries a widow will often have a dead man’s head thrown into the dish.
He who dresses ion others’ clothes will be undressed on the highway.
He who eats the king’s cow lean, pays for it fat.
He who follows his own advice must take the consequences.
He who has a glass roof should not throw stones at his neighbour’s.
He who is everybody’s friend is either very poor or very rich.
He who loves Peter won’t harm his dog.
He who marries a widow will often have a dead man’s head thrown in his dish.
He who plants the lettuce doesn’t always eat the salad.
He who talks a lot is bound to be right sometimes.
He who tells his own secret will hardly keep another’s.
He who would thrive must follow the church, the sea, or the king’s service.
He whose house is tiled with glass should not throw stones at his neighbour’s.
Her father’s fortune will make the ugliest girl attractive.
Her left hand doesn’t know what her right hand is doing.
His courage oozed out at his fingers’ ends.
How nice it is to see the rain without getting wet.
Hunger drives the wolf out of the woods.
Husband, don’t see; Wife, be blind.
I don’t care what people say as long as I get what want.
I don’t count them to you, wife, but a hog makes twelve puddings.
I don’t want it, I don’t want it, but put it into my hood.
I don’t want the cheese; I just want out of the trap.
I like not fair terms and a villain’s mind.
I thought I had made the sign of the cross — and I hurt my eye.
If a job is worth doing, it’s worth doing well.
If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again. Never say die.
If it is good then the deed is more important than the intention; if it’s bad then the intention is worse than the deed.
If someone cannot even keep his own secrets, don’t count on him to keep someone else’s.
If the eyes don’t see, the heart won’t break.
If there’s no bread, cakes are very good.
If you can’t bite, don’t show your teeth.
If you can’t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.
If you don’t pay a servant his wages, then he will pay himself.
If you don’t have what it takes you won’t get on in the world.
If you go away, you can’t expect people to keep your place for you.
If you lie down with dogs, you’ll get up with fleas.
If you live like that, you’re bound to come to a bad end.
If you pay what you owe, what you’re worth you’ll know.
If you talk too much you’re likely to give yourself away.
If you tell your secret to your friend, you will make him your master.
If you think the worst, you won’t be far wrong.
If you want a fine wife, don’t pick her on a Sunday.
If you want to watch, you’d better keep quiet.
If your roof is made of glass, don’t throw stones at your neighbor’s house.
I’ll marry, and eat the prime of the pot, and sit down first.
In a choice between bad company and loneliness — the second is preferable.
In a smith’s house the knife is wooden.
In a soap maker’s house, a person who doesn’t fall, slips.
In a wood don’t walk behind another.
In the bagpiper’s house they are all dancers.
In the presence of your neighbor don’t praise your wife or his.
In the rich woman’s house she always commands; he never.
In trouble to be troubled is to have your trouble doubled.
It is a bad hen that eats at your house and lays at another’s.
It is a loss of soap to wash the ass’s head.
It is better if they say "He ran away here" than "He died here."
It is better to conceal one’s knowledge than to reveal one’s ignorance.
It is better to strive with a stubborn ass than to carry the wood on one’s back.
It is not in the pilot’s power to prevent the wind from blowing.
It makes no difference. It’s as broad as it is long.
It’s a Small world.
It’s better to arrive on time than to be invited.
It’s better to be on your own than with people you don’t like.
It’s dogged as does it.
It’s enough to make a parson swear, or a Quaker kick his mother.
It’s just a question of putting two and two together.
It’s like talking to a brick wall.
It’s like water off a duck’s back.
It’s more blessed to give than to receive.
It’s no crime to steal from a thief.
It’s not the end of the world. Worse things happened at sea.
It’s not the same to talk of bulls as to be in the bullring.
It’s not worth crying over spilt milk.
It’s the grinding of his teeth that awakes the blacksmith’s dog, not the noise of the hammer.
I’ve fried my sausage in better pans than these.
Large thongs of another man’s leather.
Laws, like the spider’s web, catch the fly and let the hawk go free.
Laws, like the spider’s webs, catch the flies and let the hawk go free.
Let the dog bark so he don’t bite me.
Let the dogs bark; it’s a sign that we are galloping ahead.
Let what is lost go for God’s sake.
Let’s get things clear.
Like a collier’s sack, bad without and worse within.
Like a parakeet that says what he knows but doesn’t know what he says.
Little birds that can sing and won’t sing must be made to sing.
Live and let live. There’s nothing so queer as folk.
Look not out for dead men’s shoes.
Love is like a mousetrap: you go in when you want, but you don’t get out when you like.
Mad love–I for you, and you for another.
Make sure you have many books and many friends—as long as they are good ones.
Make your affairs known in the marketplace, and one will call them black and another white.
Manual jokes are clown’s jokes.
Manual play, clown’s play.
Memory is everyone’s friend — it leaves you when you need it most.
Memory is life’s clock.
Men are just as God made them — and a little worse.
Misers’ money goes twice to market.
Money soothes more than a gentleman’s words.
Money will do more than my lord’s letter.
Much pleasure and little grief is every man’s desire.
My gossips don’t like me because I tell them truths.
My neighbour’s goat gives more milk than mine.
My neighbour’s hen lays more eggs than mine.
My sister’s son is a kinsman beyond dispute.
Nae man can baith sup an’ blaw thegither.
Never show the truth naked — just in its shirt.
Of other men’s leather large thongs.
Of two evils choose the least.
On a fool’s beard all learn to shave.
One can’t ring the bells and walk in the procession.
One man’s meat is another man’s poison.
One man’s punishment is a deterrent to many.
One’s prog does not clog.
Opportunity never knocks twice at any man’s door.
Other folks’ cares kill the ass.
Pay me back what you owe me; we’ll talk later about what I owe you.
Play’s gude, while it is play.
Plough wet or dry, and you will not have to kiss your neighbour’s breech.
Problems don’t seem so bad if you keep cheerful.
Right or wrong, ’tis our house up to the roof.
Say nothing when you are giving—only say something when you are receiving.
Say nothing when you give — only when you receive.
See to it that you have many books and many friends — but be sure they are good ones.
Serve a lord and you’ll know what is grief.
So wise, so young, they say, do ne’er live long.
Soup must be hot — insults cold.
Tell me who you live with and I will tell you who you are.
Tell your friend a lie — and if he keeps it a secret, tell him the truth.
That’s a wise delay which makes the road safe.
The bachelor is a peacock, the fiance is a lion and the married man a mule.
The best feed of a horse is his master’s eye.
The body of the pope takes up no more room than the sexton’s.
The busy fly is in every man’s dish.
The chickens have come home to roost. You’re suffering the consequences now.
The day you marry ’tis either kill or cure.
The devil climbs the bell tower in a priest’s cassock.
The devil gets into the belfry by the vicar’s skirts.
The devil makes his Christmas pies of lawyers’ tongues and clerk’s fingers.
The earth hides as it takes, the physician’s mistakes.
The envious man’s face grows sharp and his eyes big.
The friar who prays in god’s name prays for two.
The gardener’s dog neither eats greens not lets any one else eat them.
The gardener’s feet do no harm to the garden.
The glass-dealer’s horses fell out, and he looked on to see which kicked hardest.
The goat can’t well cover herself with her tail.
The hunchback does not see his own hump, but sees his companion’s.
The judge’s son goes into the courtroom without fear.
The kite’s malady, its wings broken and its beak sound.
The lion’s not half so fierce as he’s painted.
The magistrate’s son gets out of every scrape.
The mare’s kick does not harm the colt.
The mare’s kicks are caresses to the horse.
The master’s foot is manure for the estate.
The mother of mischief is no bigger than a midge’s wing.
The mouse does not leave the cat’s house with a bellyful.
The obscure we see eventually; the completely apparent takes longer.
The official who can’t lie may as well be out of the world.
The person seeking India’s riches must have them within himself.
The pig’s tail will never make a good arrow.
The poor writer blames the pen.
The secret of patience is to do something else in the meantime.
The sharper the storm, the sooner it’s over.
The shoemaker’s son always goes barefoot.
The smith’s dog sleeps at the noise of the hammer, and wakes at the grinding of teeth.
The spider’s web lets the rat escape and catches the fly.
The well-dressed woman draws her husband away from another woman’s door.
The wolf picks up the ass’s fleas by moonlight.
The woman who dresses well attracts the husband from another woman’s door.
There are no birds in last year’s nest.
There is never a great dunghill at a sportsman’s door.
There is no woman who sleeps so deeply that the sound of a guitar won’t bring her to the window.
There is no worse apprentice than the one who doesn’t want to know.
There wasn’t a sound to be heard. You could have heard a pin drop.
There’s honor among thieves.
There’s no accounting for taste.
There’s no argument like that of the stick.
There’s no making a good cloak of bad cloth.
There’s no smoke without fire.
There’s no substitute for experience.
There’s nothing so queer as folk.
They who don’t keep goats and yet sell kids, where do they get them?
They who don’t kill pigs must not expect black-puddings.
This is the milkmaid’s tale.
Though your bloodhound be gentle, don’t bite him on the lip.
Three things are not to be trusted; a cow’s horn, a dog’s tooth, and a horse’s hoof.
To change one’s mind is rather a sign of prudence than ignorance.
To friend and foe alike I tell them how bad she is, so that I don’t have to share her with anyone.
To lather an ass’s head is only wasting soap.
Today is yesterday’s pupil.
Tomorrow is often the busiest day of the week.
To-morrow’s remedy will not ward off the evil of to-day.
Truth and oil always come to the surface.
Two blacks don’t make a white.
Watch out for the dog that doesn’t bark and the man who says nothing.
We all have a little bit of musician, poet and crazy person in ourselves.
We’ll just have to make do.
We’re all a little crazy in one way or another.
What can’t be cured must be endured.
What is another’s always pines for its master.
What is mine is my own; my brother Juan’s is his and mine.
What’s everybody’s business is nobody’s business.
When a good offer comes for your daughter, don’t wait till her father returns from market.
When the cat’s away, the mice will play.
When the cat’s away the rats will play.
When there is real danger, the dogs don’t bark.
When you can’t get bread, oat-cakes are not amiss.
When you can’t get meat, chickens and bacon are good.
When you eat new bread, don’t drink water.
Where there is love there is pain.
Where there’s a will there’s a way.
Where there’s fire there’s smoke.
Where there’s gossiping, there’s lying.
Where there’s muck, there’s money.
Where there’s smoke, there’s fire.
Where there’s whispering, there’s lying.
Whether you ignore a pig, or worship that pig from afar, to the pig it’s all the same.
Whilst we drink, prank ourselves, with wenches daily, Old age upon’s at unawares doth sally.
Who arrays himself in other men’s garments is stripped on the highway.
Who is always prying into other men’s affairs, leads a dangerous life.
Whom God will destroy, he first makes mad.
Wipe the nose of your neighbour’s son, and marry him to your daughter.
With money you would not know yourself; without money nobody would know you.
Wit’s never bought till it’s paid for.
You can lead a horse to water, but you can’t make it drink.
You can’t catch trout with dry breeches.
You can’t have more bed-bugs than a blanket-full.
You can’t have more bugs than a blanketfull.
You can’t have your cake and eat it too.
spanish.description: If you eat your cake, you won’t have it anymore, will you? So you can’t do both. This proverb is about having two opposite desires, and how it’s impossible to get both. Its meaning is similar to the proverb, “You can’t have the best of both worlds.”

spanish.text: You can’t make an omelet without breaking eggs.
You can’t make bricks without straw.
You can’t make pancakes without breaking eggs.
You can’t serve God and Mammon.
You can’t win them all.
You have debts, and make debts still; if you’ve not lied, lie you will.
You’re casting pearls before swine.
You’ve made bed, and now you’ll have to lie in it.
To whom you tell your secrets you resign your liberty.
He, who helps everybody, helps nobody.
He, who knows how to live, knows enough.
He that would have a beautiful wife should choose her on a Sunday.
The wind changes every day, a woman every second.
Many things grow in the garden that was never sown there.
More grows in the garden than the gardener sows.
If you have the moon, ignore the stars.
A horse is worth more than riches.
It is better to be a mouse in a cat’s mouth than a man in a lawyer’s hands.
Tell me what you brag about and I’ll tell you what you lack.
Even the best writer has to erase.
Spanish is the language of lovers; Italian is for the singer, French for diplomats, and German for horses.
Never ask of him who has, but of him who wishes you well.
Say nothing when you are giving — only say something when you are receiving.
A secret between two is God’s secret, between three is all men’s.
Love, pain, and money cannot be kept secret. They soon betray themselves.
An ounce of mother is worth a ton of priest.
What children heart heir parents say by the fireside, they repeat in the highway.
If you want to be respected, respect yourself.
You cannot catch trout with dry breeches.
Don’t worry if people call you ordinary — only if you areordinary.
Walk till the blood appears on the cheek, but not the seat on the brow.
Wipe the nose of your neighbor’s son and let him marry your daughter.
An ounce of mother is worth a pound of clergy.
The belly rules the mind.
There is no remedy for death, but death itself is a remedy.
Never praise life in front of death, or the beautiful day in front of night.
Life without a friend is death without a witness.
In the face of love and death, courage is useless.
Death is the reaper who doesn’t take a midday nap.
Better a quiet death than a public misfortune.
It takes two to quarrel, but only one to end it.
There’s no argument like that of the stick.
Sleep is the best cure for waking troubles.
Trouble will rain on those who are already wet.
The patient who names a doctor his heir makes a big mistake.
He is always right who suspects that he makes mistakes.
It takes two to make a quarrel, but only one to end it.
Beauty and chastity are always quarreling.
Wrinkles are the gravestones of love.
If there is still doubt do not accuse.
He is always right who suspects that he makes mistakes.
An old dog does not bark in vain.
Too many cooks spoil the broth
spanish.description: If there are many people doing the same job, the result will come out to be bad.

spanish.text: Discretion is the better part of courage .
Hope is a good breakfast but a bad supper.
Everyone sees things from his own point of view.
Cow of many–well milked and badly fed.
Hell is paved with good intentions
A single occurrence is insufficient to prove a theory or establish a rule.
If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again.
Don’t worry if people call you ordinary … only if you are ordinary.
If wishes were horses … then beggars would ride.
Courtesy does not exclude courage.
Beggars can’t be choosers.
spanish.description: We use this common proverb when we do not have enough money to get what we want but only what we need.

spanish.text: Dirty clothes are washed at home.
For a good appetite there is no hard bread.
Truth is time’s daughter
You can’t escape your destiny.
Don´t mention the hangman’s noose in the house of someone who died by it.
Curiosity killed the cat.
spanish.description: A polite way of telling someone to “Mind your own business”. Pay attention to your own life, ignore things that don’t concern you.

spanish.text: What has been promised, is debt.
Bad news flies.
Happiness is never quite perfect. There’ll always be some trouble or displeasure.
Debts are like children, the smaller they are the louder they scream.
Truth will out.
Eat, drink and be merry (for tomorrow we die).
Also of hope and aspiration do we live.
Compare your griefs with other men’s and they will seem less.
Honor buys no meat in the market.
A secret between two is God’s secret, between three is all men.
Fools walk in where angels fear to tread.
I wept when I was born and as each day passes I know why.
All talk and no action.
Time is a great healer.
Each person knows where his shoe hurts.
Time doesn’t stand still.
The sap rises in the spring.
Better keep now than seek anon.
Hunger sharpens the wit.
You can’t please everybody.
Do not rejoice at my grief, for when mine is told, yours will be new.
Opportunity knocks only once.
spanish.description: Always seize an opportunity when it comes your way as you may not get another chance at it.
